citations.narrative:
Primary enclosures failed to protect birds from injury.
***On September 25, 2023 a 1-year-old domestic bantam rooster was found not moving in a pool in the “Duckling Pen”.
After extensive medical interventions and treatments, the animal died. According to medical records and conversations
with staff and the Attending Veterinarian and clinical veterinarian, the rooster died as a result of drowning in the pool. Prior
to its death, the animal had been housed for approximately 3 weeks with another chicken in an enclosure adjacent to the
“Duckling Pen”. On the day of its death, the rooster (who was not flight restricted) flew over an approximately 3-foot tall
baby gate into an adjacent enclosure (the “duckling pen”) which contained a pool of water used for ducklings. The pool of
water was square, approximately 4 feet wide by 4 foot long, and the sides of the pool were steep and smooth. The depth
of the pool in the center was approximately 3 feet deep. Facility staff believe that the rooster fell into the pool and couldn't
get out. The facility has since covered the pool so it is no longer accessible to birds in the enclosure.
***Disposition records show that two North American ruddy ducks “disappeared”, and facility staff and the Attending
Veterinarian stated that the animals were lost to predation, most likely racoons. The facility searched for the birds
thoroughly for multiple days, and officially documented the disappearances on October 31st and October 23rd, 2023 in
facility records. The birds had been living in the “Teton Marsh Exhibit”, which contains a pond and natural marshy areas,
and also houses a variety of waterfowl. The back walls of the enclosure are six-foot-tall chain link, and the front of the
enclosure is an elevated public walkway bordered by an approximately 4-foot tall wire and wooden fence. The birds were
flight restricted (pinioned). The facility has a predator control program in place and has undertaken measures to prevent
additional predation near this exhibit.
Birds that are not protected from hazards or predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death.
Correct by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and
restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrected at the time of
inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The enrichment plan for nonhuman primates does not address special considerations for infants and young juveniles,
animals showing signs of psychological distress, individually housed primates that are unable to see and hear other
primates of their own or compatible species, and great apes. While the facility has a detailed and robust enrichment
program for animals, the written plan does not include these special considerations.
Enrichment, including special consideration for the groups listed above, is important for ensuring the health and wellbeing
of nonhuman primates. Enrichment is important for relieving stress, ensuring normal development of young animals, and
for allowing the expression of species-typical behaviors.
Correct by ensuring that the written enrichment plan for nonhuman primates contains all of the elements required under
the Animal Welfare Act regulations.

The facility failed to conduct or failed to maintain complete records of water sampling for marine mammal pools at the
minimum frequency required by the Animal Welfare Act (AWA).
***Review of water quality records for the pools housing California sea lions show no water quality test results for pH or
salinity on 9/20/23, 9/21/23, 9/10/23, 8/22/23, 5/30/23 (record noted, “crazy day, no sample collected”), and 1/20/23. The
water system does have a probe that reads pH in real time, however, the results are not recorded for the days in question.
***Review of water quality records for the polar bear pool (which contains fresh water) do not contain test results for 15
dates in 2023 (8/5, 7/29, 7/21, 7/15, 6/24, 5/30, 5/20, 3/31, 3/18, 3/3, 2/16, 2/9, 1/17, 1/16, 1/13). The water system does
have a probe that reads pH in real time, however, the results are not recorded for the days in question.
Testing for water quality in marine mammal pools is important for ensuring that water is safe for marine mammals who
use the pools. Lack of water quality testing may result in delays in detecting water quality issues which may affect animal
health.
Correct by testing marine mammal pools at least the minimum frequency required by the AWA.

There are large piles of mulch next to the perimeter fence in the east end of the facility, adjacent to North Parkway Road.
The perimeter fence in this area is less than 8-feet tall, due to the presence of the mulch piles against the fence. In some
areas, the distance from the surface of the mulch pile (where it touches the fence) to the top of the fence is 5-feet, making
the effective height of the fence 5-feet. The facility houses dangerous animals (including gorilla, big cats, and polar bear)
which require perimeter fencing that is at least 8-feet tall.
Perimeter fencing is important for acting as a secondary containment system in the event that an animal escapes from its
primary enclosure, and for preventing unauthorized animals and people from entering the facility.
Correct by ensuring that perimeter fencing is at least 8-feet tall in all areas, and maintained in good repair.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The enrichment plan for birds does not address special considerations for nestlings, chicks, or fledglings; birds showing
signs of psychological distress; or individually housed birds of a social species that are unable to see and hear birds of
their own or compatible species. While the facility has a detailed and robust enrichment program for birds, the written plan
does not include these special considerations.
Enrichment, including special consideration for the groups listed above, is important for ensuring the health and wellbeing
of birds. Enrichment is important for relieving stress, ensuring normal development of young birds, and for allowing the
expression of species-typical behaviors.
Correct by ensuring that the written enrichment plan for birds contains all of the elements required under the Animal
Welfare Act regulations.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility
representatives.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 25th, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
KATHRYN VERNON, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Primary enclosures failed to protect birds from injury.  
***On September 25, 2023 a 1-year-old domestic bantam rooster was found not moving in a pool in the “Duckling Pen”. 
After extensive medical interventions and treatments, the animal died. According to medical records and conversations

restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrected at the time of 
inspection. 
3.81(c) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The enrichment plan for nonhuman primates does not address special considerations for infants and young juveniles, 
animals showing signs of psychological distress, individually housed primates that are unable to see and hear other 
primates of their own or compatible species, and great apes. While the facility has a detailed and robust enrichment

program for animals, the written plan does not include these special considerations.  
Enrichment, including special consideration for the groups listed above, is important for ensuring the health and wellbeing 
of nonhuman primates. Enrichment is important for relieving stress, ensuring normal development of young animals, and 
for allowing the expression of species-typical behaviors.  
Correct by ensuring that the written enrichment plan for nonhuman primates contains all of the elements required under 
the Animal Welfare Act regulations. 
3.106(b)(3) 
   
Water quality. 
The facility failed to conduct or failed to maintain complete records of water sampling for marine mammal pools at the 
minimum frequency required by the Animal Welfare Act (AWA).  
***Review of water quality records for the pools housing California sea lions show no water quality test results for pH or

***Review of water quality records for the polar bear pool (which contains fresh water) do not contain test results for 15 
dates in 2023 (8/5, 7/29, 7/21, 7/15, 6/24, 5/30, 5/20, 3/31, 3/18, 3/3, 2/16, 2/9, 1/17, 1/16, 1/13). The water system does 
have a probe that reads pH in real time, however, the results are not recorded for the days in question.  
Testing for water quality in marine mammal pools is important for ensuring that water is safe for marine mammals who 
use the pools. Lack of water quality testing may result in delays in detecting water quality issues which may affect animal 
health.  
Correct by testing marine mammal pools at least the minimum frequency required by the AWA. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There are large piles of mulch next to the perimeter fence in the east end of the facility, adjacent to North Parkway Road. 
The perimeter fence in this area is less than 8-feet tall, due to the presence of the mulch piles against the fence. In some 
areas, the distance from the surface of the mulch pile (where it touches the fence) to the top of the fence is 5-feet, making 
the effective height of the fence 5-feet. The facility houses dangerous animals (including gorilla, big cats, and polar bear) 
which require perimeter fencing that is at least 8-feet tall.  
Perimeter fencing is important for acting as a secondary containment system in the event that an animal escapes from its 
primary enclosure, and for preventing unauthorized animals and people from entering the facility.  
Correct by ensuring that perimeter fencing is at least 8-feet tall in all areas, and maintained in good repair. 
3.154(c) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The enrichment plan for birds does not address special considerations for nestlings, chicks, or fledglings; birds showing 
signs of psychological distress; or individually housed birds of a social species that are unable to see and hear birds of 
their own or compatible species. While the facility has a detailed and robust enrichment program for birds, the written plan 
does not include these special considerations.  
Enrichment, including special consideration for the groups listed above, is important for ensuring the health and wellbeing 
of birds. Enrichment is important for relieving stress, ensuring normal development of young birds, and for allowing the

expression of species-typical behaviors. 
Correct by ensuring that the written enrichment plan for birds contains all of the elements required under the Animal 
Welfare Act regulations. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility 
representatives. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 25th, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
KATHRYN VERNON, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
